<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Good morning. </strong>It’s not often we get to say this but it is <em>my </em>pleasure to bring you the Brew this morning. To try to make sense of this crazy year, the Morning Brew writing crew will be serving up a slew of special edition newsletters to close out 2020. Through New Year’s Day, we’ll publish a series of essays touching on all those deep questions we’ve faced this year—think big-picture stuff like how the business world embraced the Black Lives Matter movement and the pandemic-era trends that might stick around. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">So pour yourself a mug of hot cocoa, add some Baileys when no one's watching, and let’s unpack what the heck happened over the past 12 months. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BUSINESS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/23/looking-role-luck-played-business-success?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Businesses Ask Themselves One Question
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="Do you feel lucky punk?" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=531 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/c2pOELjarKcU/giphy.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="Do you feel lucky punk?" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/c2pOELjarKcU/giphy.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">At the end of each episode of my favorite podcast, <em>How I Built This, </em>host Guy Raz asks his guests, all of whom have built massively successful businesses, “How much of your success is because of your hard work, skills, and smarts, and how much of it is luck?” A number of the talented entrepreneurs inevitably admit that luck played a role. And after 2020 gave certain industries pandemic wedgies (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/22/shortterm-future-travel-regional?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">travel</a>) and others golden tickets (<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/home-improvement-sector-surprisingly-well?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">home improvement</a>), that question is more relevant than ever.</p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The lucky ones</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom: </strong>The fact that I’m having trouble coming up with a WFH joke right now shows just how many stories we’ve written about Zoom since March. The videoconferencing company wouldn’t trade a holographic Charizard for the year it’s had, all thanks to the “good luck” of the pandemic forcing tens of millions of people to set up home-offices in their pantries. Zoom’s revenue was up 367% from a year ago in Q3; its stock is up nearly 600% this year alone. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Peloton: </strong>Another company that hit the lotto while being struck by lightning, Peloton has wheeled its hardware (bikes, treadmills) into a <em>lot</em> more households this year thanks to the pandemic.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>On June 30, the number of people subscribing to its remote fitness classes reached </span><span><a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-posts-first-ever-profit-as-pandemic-speeds-sales-11599776415?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">~1.1 million</a></span><span>, up from 886,100 at the end of March. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">And while many companies struggled to keep the lights on in their unused offices, Peloton’s biggest challenge was making enough bikes to deliver to impatient customers.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Fiverr:</strong> An under-the-radar pandemic winner, Fiverr is a marketplace for remote freelancers. Its <a href="https://beth.technology/fiverr-explosive-growth-with-a-bright-future/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Service-as-a-Product</a> offering is tailor-made for a business landscape where part-time remote workers are in heavy demand. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Novavax:</strong> Talk about a business that is booming. The small biotech started the year essentially as a penny stock. It had no FDA-approved drugs and no profits. But once the coronavirus hit and Novavax announced it had a vaccine candidate in development, the stock went ballistic. It’s up *checks notes, rubs eyes, mutters “Oh, wow”* over <a href="https://www.barchart.com/stocks/performance/percent-change/advances?timeFrame=ytd&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">2,700%</a> this year. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But as any tipsy trip to the roulette table can tell you, luck is a double-edged sword. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">The pandemic has put Zoom in an awkward position, according to Packy McCormick, writer of the <a href="https://notboring.substack.com/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Not Boring</a> newsletter: “Zoom’s attracted a ton of competitors and they’ve been forced to focus on security and reliability versus building anything new.” Revenue is way up, but that growth spurt may have come at the expense of a more sustainable trajectory that would put it in a better position over the long-run. “Yes [Zoom] has been lucky, but in some cases, is it too much of a good thing?” McCormick told me. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Peloton’s ankles are also showing after it outgrew its 2019 pants. Record sales have exposed cracks in its <a href="https://www.supplychaindive.com/news/coronavirus-peloton-deliver-pandemic-demand-surge/577656/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">supply chain</a>, and it recently had to <a href="https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/peloton-slips-a-gear-on-recall-supply-chain-delivery-challenges-60862890?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">issue a recall</a> on 27,000 pedals because of a safety risk. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Still, growing pains are good, because it means you’re...growing. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">The raw end of the deal</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">For every Peloton and Zoom, there were thousands of small businesses forced to close despite having thriving operations before the pandemic. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Because of the nature of the lockdowns, restaurants have been particularly unlucky. Data from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce shows that 82% of jobs lost since February have been in the <a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/15/small-businesses-are-in-survival-mode-as-the-covid-pandemic-drags-on.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">service industry</a>. And in California, one of a few states to ban indoor dining two separate times, the National Restaurant Association predicts <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/dec/14/people-are-desperate-california-shutdown-pushes-businesses-to-breaking-point?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">43% of restaurants will permanently close</a> because of the current crisis. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But even on a restaurant-by-restaurant basis, some were unluckier than others. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The Fat Radish, an upscale NYC eatery, was </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/14/the-fat-radishs-unlucky-cohort-1-in-3-ny-restaurants-wont-open-post-pandemic.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">forced to close</a></span><span> in July because it didn’t have the street space to take advantage of outdoor dining.</span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>But at Loulou Petit Bistro, just one neighborhood away, “We are lucky to have a large outdoor section with close to 80 seats and...dedicated heaters,” owner Mathias Van Leyden </span><span><a href="https://www.timeout.com/newyork/news/nyc-indoor-dining-banheres-what-restaurants-have-to-say-121120?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">told Time Out</a></span><span>. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Business survival didn’t come down to great food, superior ambiance, or servers who memorize your order without writing it down. Sometimes, it was determined simply by whether your location could accommodate outdoor dining.  </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Look to the cookie</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">As easy as it would be to fit businesses neatly into the categories of “lucky” or “unlucky” during the pandemic, the reality for most companies isn’t as black and white as the <em>Seinfeld</em> cookie. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>
</span><span><strong style="color:#000">Take Disney:</strong></span><span> Its parks business, which accounts for 23% of its revenue, was devastated this year. It took an </span><span><a href="https://www.investopedia.com/how-disney-makes-money-4799164?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">$81 million operating <em>loss</em></a></span><span><em> </em></span><span>in FY 2020</span><span><em> </em></span><span>after netting $6.8 billion in profit in FY 2019.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">But Baby Yoda, <em>Hamilton</em>, and “Let It Go” saved the day. Disney would be in a (small) world of hurt right now had it not launched Disney+ five months before the pandemic. And Disney+ might not have gotten an astonishing 86 million subscribers if parents hadn’t been stuck at home with bored kids. But those things happened because of Disney’s foresight to launch a competitor to Netflix loaded with its own great IP, plus a lot of luck. Now, after telling the world it’s <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/10/disney-announces-disney-content-slate?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">all-in on streaming</a> during its most recent investor day, Disney’s stock is at an all time high. And Baby Yoda could likely run for president.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Bottom line:</strong> After 2020, I'm guessing a lot more guests on Guy Raz's show will give additional weight to the role of luck. Blood, sweat, tears, and even genius were no match for simply being in the right—or wrong—place at the right time.</p>

<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><em>Get to know the Brew better with a quick round of icebreaker questions. </em></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Hometown: </strong>Bradenton, FL</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What you would be doing if not writing for the Brew:</strong> I would make a content house where some aspirational golf lovers and I would quit everything to try and make it onto a pro tour, documenting our journey along the way.  </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">One thing you are snobby about:</strong> I won’t eat even marginally expired foods. Even though I know milk doesn’t go bad the moment the date on the carton passes, I just can’t make myself ingest something after the approved timeframe for consumption. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">First R-rated movie: </strong><em>Love, Actually</em>. My parents are obsessed with it and showed it to me way earlier than they should have. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">What is something fun you did that you’d never do again? </strong>Short Tesla. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">If you could safely eat any inedible object, what would it be? </strong>I think a brand new tennis ball would be a light and refreshing snack. The delicious chemical smell, the crisp sound of opening a new tube...my mouth is watering already.   </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Recommend literally anything</strong>: If your computer doth protest too much when you open more than seven tabs, you have to try the <a href="https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/onetab/chphlpgkkbolifaimnlloiipkdnihall?hl=en&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">OneTab Chrome extension</a>. One click and it saves all your open tabs for later access. The best part: It frees up memory in the process so everything feels snappy again. Can’t live without it in the newsletter game.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In November, we released our first <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/11/03/run-zoom-trivia-night?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Morning Brew Virtual Trivia Night</a> to help people connect with their friends, family, and coworkers. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">In <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/22/run-zoom-trivia-night-edition-no-2?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">this document</a>, you’ll find everything you need to run virtual trivia. <p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Here’s a sample question to whet your trivia appetite: Within the categories below, which is the <em>first </em>entry in alphabetical order? </p>

style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nBUSINESS\n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/23/looking-role-luck-played-business-success?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nBusinesses Ask Themselves One Question\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"Do you feel lucky punk?\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=531 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/c2pOELjarKcU/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"Do you feel lucky punk?\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/c2pOELjarKcU/giphy.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAt the end of each episode of my favorite podcast, \u003cem\u003eHow I Built This, \u003c/em\u003ehost Guy Raz asks his guests, all of whom have built massively successful businesses, “How much of your success is because of your hard work, skills, and smarts, and how much of it is luck?” A number of the talented entrepreneurs inevitably admit that luck played a role. And after 2020 gave certain industries pandemic wedgies (\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/05/22/shortterm-future-travel-regional?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etravel\u003c/a\u003e) and others golden tickets (\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/06/19/home-improvement-sector-surprisingly-well?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ehome improvement\u003c/a\u003e), that question is more relevant than ever.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe lucky ones\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom: \u003c/strong\u003eThe fact that I’m having trouble coming up with a WFH joke right now shows just how many stories we’ve written about Zoom since March. The videoconferencing company wouldn’t trade a holographic Charizard for the year it’s had, all thanks to the “good luck” of the pandemic forcing tens of millions of people to set up home-offices in their pantries. Zoom’s revenue was up 367% from a year ago in Q3; its stock is up nearly 600% this year alone. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003ePeloton: \u003c/strong\u003eAnother company that hit the lotto while being struck by lightning, Peloton has wheeled its hardware (bikes, treadmills) into a \u003cem\u003elot\u003c/em\u003e more households this year thanks to the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eOn June 30, the number of people subscribing to its remote fitness classes reached \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/peloton-posts-first-ever-profit-as-pandemic-speeds-sales-11599776415?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e~1.1 million\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e, up from 886,100 at the end of March. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAnd while many companies struggled to keep the lights on in their unused offices, Peloton’s biggest challenge was making enough bikes to deliver to impatient customers.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFiverr:\u003c/strong\u003e An under-the-radar pandemic winner, Fiverr is a marketplace for remote freelancers. Its \u003ca href=\"https://beth.technology/fiverr-explosive-growth-with-a-bright-future/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eService-as-a-Product\u003c/a\u003e offering is tailor-made for a business landscape where part-time remote workers are in heavy demand. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eNovavax:\u003c/strong\u003e Talk about a business that is booming. The small biotech started the year essentially as a penny stock. It had no FDA-approved drugs and no profits. But once the coronavirus hit and Novavax announced it had a vaccine candidate in development, the stock went ballistic. It’s up *checks notes, rubs eyes, mutters “Oh, wow”* over \u003ca href=\"https://www.barchart.com/stocks/performance/percent-change/advances?timeFrame=ytd\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e2,700%\u003c/a\u003e this year. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut as any tipsy trip to the roulette table can tell you, luck is a double-edged sword. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eThe pandemic has put Zoom in an awkward position, according to Packy McCormick, writer of the \u003ca href=\"https://notboring.substack.com/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eNot Boring\u003c/a\u003e newsletter: “Zoom’s attracted a ton of competitors and they’ve been forced to focus on security and reliability versus building anything new.” Revenue is way up, but that growth spurt may have come at the expense of a more sustainable trajectory that would put it in a better position over the long-run. “Yes [Zoom] has been lucky, but in some cases, is it too much of a good thing?” McCormick told me. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePeloton’s ankles are also showing after it outgrew its 2019 pants. Record sales have exposed cracks in its \u003ca href=\"https://www.supplychaindive.com/news/coronavirus-peloton-deliver-pandemic-demand-surge/577656/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esupply chain\u003c/a\u003e, and it recently had to \u003ca href=\"https://www.spglobal.com/marketintelligence/en/news-insights/latest-news-headlines/peloton-slips-a-gear-on-recall-supply-chain-delivery-challenges-60862890?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eissue a recall\u003c/a\u003e on 27,000 pedals because of a safety risk. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eStill, growing pains are good, because it means you’re...growing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eThe raw end of the deal\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eFor every Peloton and Zoom, there were thousands of small businesses forced to close despite having thriving operations before the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBecause of the nature of the lockdowns, restaurants have been particularly unlucky. Data from the U.S. Chamber of Commerce shows that 82% of jobs lost since February have been in the \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/15/small-businesses-are-in-survival-mode-as-the-covid-pandemic-drags-on.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eservice industry\u003c/a\u003e. And in California, one of a few states to ban indoor dining two separate times, the National Restaurant Association predicts \u003ca href=\"https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/dec/14/people-are-desperate-california-shutdown-pushes-businesses-to-breaking-point?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e43% of restaurants will permanently close\u003c/a\u003e because of the current crisis. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut even on a restaurant-by-restaurant basis, some were unluckier than others. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe Fat Radish, an upscale NYC eatery, was \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/08/14/the-fat-radishs-unlucky-cohort-1-in-3-ny-restaurants-wont-open-post-pandemic.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eforced to close\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e in July because it didn’t have the street space to take advantage of outdoor dining.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eBut at Loulou Petit Bistro, just one neighborhood away, “We are lucky to have a large outdoor section with close to 80 seats and...dedicated heaters,” owner Mathias Van Leyden \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.timeout.com/newyork/news/nyc-indoor-dining-banheres-what-restaurants-have-to-say-121120?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etold Time Out\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBusiness survival didn’t come down to great food, superior ambiance, or servers who memorize your order without writing it down. Sometimes, it was determined simply by whether your location could accommodate outdoor dining.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eLook to the cookie\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eAs easy as it would be to fit businesses neatly into the categories of “lucky” or “unlucky” during the pandemic, the reality for most companies isn’t as black and white as the \u003cem\u003eSeinfeld\u003c/em\u003e cookie. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eTake Disney:\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e Its parks business, which accounts for 23% of its revenue, was devastated this year. It took an \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.investopedia.com/how-disney-makes-money-4799164?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003e$81 million operating \u003cem\u003eloss\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003ein FY 2020\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cem\u003e \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eafter netting $6.8 billion in profit in FY 2019.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBut Baby Yoda, \u003cem\u003eHamilton\u003c/em\u003e, and “Let It Go” saved the day. Disney would be in a (small) world of hurt right now had it not launched Disney+ five months before the pandemic. And Disney+ might not have gotten an astonishing 86 million subscribers if parents hadn’t been stuck at home with bored kids. But those things happened because of Disney’s foresight to launch a competitor to Netflix loaded with its own great IP, plus a lot of luck. Now, after telling the world it’s \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/12/10/disney-announces-disney-content-slate?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eall-in on streaming\u003c/a\u003e during its most recent investor day, Disney’s stock is at an all time high. And Baby Yoda could likely run for president.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eBottom line:\u003c/strong\u003e After 2020, I'm guessing a lot more guests on Guy Raz's show will give additional weight to the role of luck. style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eHometown: \u003c/strong\u003eBradenton, FL\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat you would be doing if not writing for the Brew:\u003c/strong\u003e I would make a content house where some aspirational golf lovers and I would quit everything to try and make it onto a pro tour, documenting our journey along the way.  \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eOne thing you are snobby about:\u003c/strong\u003e I won’t eat even marginally expired foods. Even though I know milk doesn’t go bad the moment the date on the carton passes, I just can’t make myself ingest something after the approved timeframe for consumption. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eFirst R-rated movie: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003eLove, Actually\u003c/em\u003e. My parents are obsessed with it and showed it to me way earlier than they should have. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eWhat is something fun you did that you’d never do again? \u003c/strong\u003eShort Tesla. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eIf you could safely eat any inedible object, what would it be? \u003c/strong\u003eI think a brand new tennis ball would be a light and refreshing snack. The delicious chemical smell, the crisp sound of opening a new tube...my mouth is watering already.   \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eRecommend literally anything\u003c/strong\u003e: If your computer doth protest too much when you open more than seven tabs, you have to try the \u003ca href=\"https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/onetab/chphlpgkkbolifaimnlloiipkdnihall?hl=en\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eOneTab Chrome extension\u003c/a\u003e.
